channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Fort McMurray Blaze, Fast and Unpredictable, Keeps Firefighters at a Distance
item.media:description: A wildfire spread on Tuesday along Highway 63, the only route out of Fort McMurray. The road became gridlocked as 80,000 people fled the city.
item.description: A wildfire that began last weekend in Alberta remained out of control on Wednesday. Its speed and shifting direction have made it too dangerous to tackle from the ground.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Matter: Bacteria-Infected Mosquitoes Could Slow Spread of Zika Virus
item.media:description: A wasp egg infected with Wolbachia, a microbe that researchers say protects mosquitoes from the Zika virus.
item.media:credit: Merijn Salverda and Richard Stouthamer/Science Source
item.description: Mosquitoes infected with the bacterium Wolbachia resist viruses like Zika and dengue. Now researchers are testing the bacterium on mosquitoes in the wild.
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER

item.title: Letter from Europe: NATO Ratchets Up Missile Defense Despite Russian Criticism
item.media:description: A United States Air Force F-22 Raptor fighter jet, which is part of the Operation Atlantic Resolve, an American commitment to NATO’s collective security and regional stability, at the Siauliai Air Base, Lithuania, in April.
item.description: A decision by the United States and its allies to proceed with ballistic missile defense is an important stage in the alliance’s new stance toward Moscow.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Ahmet Davutoglu, Turkey’s Prime Minister, Is Expected to Be Replaced
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, left, and Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu at the start of their meeting in Ankara on Wednesday.
item.description: Mr. Davutoglu’s departure is occurring amid a disagreement with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who is seeking more power.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Comedian Criticizes Merkel’s Response to Lampoon of Turkish Leader
item.media:description: Jan Böhmermann, a German satirist who earned plaudits but also criticism when he skewered President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey on his TV show.
item.description: Jan Böhmermann, whose poem about Recep Tayyip Erdogan stirred a diplomatic storm, said Chancellor Angela Merkel “filleted and served me with tea” by allowing the Turkish president to sue him.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Iran Accuses U.S. of Meddling as Tensions Grow
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry in New York last month with Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif of Iran.
item.description: Iran threatened to block a Persian Gulf access route and denounced what it called the American “meddling approach and tone.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Partial Truce in Syria Is Said to Extend to Aleppo
item.media:description: Damaged buildings in the Bab al-Hadid neighborhood of Aleppo, Syria, on Monday. Nearly 300 people, mostly civilians, have died in renewed fighting there.
item.description: American officials and Syrian state television said a partial truce now applied to the divided city, but it was unclear when the extension took effect.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Woman’s Mundane Query Turns Into Surreal Court Scuffle
item.media:description: Ye Jinghuan, in Beijing in April.
item.description: The woman needed a simple police document. Before it was all over, she was on the floor, and then behind bars.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Kim Jong-un Seeks to Cement Power at First North Korean Congress in 36 Years
item.media:description: Participants in the seventh congress of the governing Workers’ Party in Pyongyang, North Korea, on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The Workers’ Party congress — in theory, the North’s highest decision-making body — will essentially be a coronation for Mr. Kim, affirming him as supreme leader.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Jean-Baptiste Bagaza, Deposed Leader of a Troubled Burundi, Is Dead at 69
item.media:description: Jean-Baptiste Bagaza in Burundi’s capital in 1984.
item.description: As president of the small Central African nation, Mr. Bagaza invested in infrastructure but did little to make his country a stable democracy.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Indonesia, Malaysia and Philippines to Bolster Security at Sea
item.media:description: Joko Widodo, center, the president of Indonesia, with officials from Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines at a meeting in the Indonesian city of Yogyakarta on Thursday focused on maritime security.
item.description: The countries agreed to conduct coordinated sea patrols and establish a hotline to combat piracy and kidnappings in surrounding waters.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Arthur R. Kroeber on ‘China’s Economy’
item.media:description: Workers welding a steel frame for an advertising billboard in Jiaxing in Zhejiang Province, China.
item.description: The managing director of Gavekal Dragonomics discusses the role of innovation and China’s potential for growth.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: ISIS Operative From Australia Is Killed in Iraq Airstrike, Officials Say
item.description: The recruiter, Neil Prakash, called the most dangerous Australian involved with the militant group, had been linked to some terrorist plots in Australia.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Another Combat Death in Iraq May Presage Future U.S. Role
item.media:description: Special Warfare Operator 1st Class Charles Keating IV.
item.description: Tuesday’s battle in Teleskof could presage a future in Iraq where American troops move even closer to routine, daily battle in the fight against ISIS.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Israel Responds to Hamas Mortar Fire With Airstrikes in Gaza Strip
item.description: The mortar rounds, fired toward Israeli defense forces, were intended to discourage Israel from excavating areas east of Gaza in a search for new tunnels.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ

item.title: Search for Family’s Lost History Leads to Mass Grave in Poland
item.media:description: Michael Pomeranc in the lobby of his hotel, Sixty SoHo. Mr. Pomeranc spent nearly three decades working to uncover the fate of his relatives.
item.media:credit: Natalie Keyssar for The New York Times
item.description: Michael Pomeranc, a New York hotelier, spent nearly three decades working to uncover the fate of his relatives who died in the Holocaust.
item.dc:creator: JULIE SATOW

item.title: David Cameron Says Britain Will Accept More Syrian Children as Refugees
item.description: The prime minister acted after a campaign in the House of Lords, led by Alf Dubs, who fled Czechoslovakia in 1939 at 6 years old.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Anti-Semitic Graffiti Appears After Spanish Village Changes Its Name
item.media:description: A street in the Spanish village of Castrillo Mota de Judíos, shown in April 2014, a month before a referendum that changed the village’s name from Castrillo Matajudíos.
item.media:credit: Markel Redondo for The New York Times
item.description: The village was once known as Castrillo Matajudíos, or Little Hill Fort of Jew Killers. Its mayor believes that the vandals are members of extremist groups with no direct connection to the village.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Europe to Remove 500-Euro Bill, the ‘Bin Laden’ Bank Note Criminals Love
item.media:description: The European Central Bank will phase out the 500-euro note by the end of 2018.
item.description: Though the effort has been portrayed as a blow to corruption and organized crime, some critics say it is as an infringement on personal freedom and a stealthy tool of monetary policy.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: British Elections Pose Test for Jeremy Corbyn, Labour Party Leader
item.media:description: Sadiq Khan, the Labour Party’s mayoral candidate, during a campaign stop at a market in London on Wednesday. He is the front-runner in the race to replace the outgoing mayor, Boris Johnson, a Conservative.
item.description: Mr. Corbyn faces continuing dissent from some of his own lawmakers. Poor results in Thursday’s elections could add to the pressure.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Hong Kong Journal: Rest in Peace ... Just Not in Gucci Loafers
item.media:description: A paper Mercedes-Benz replica is taken in to Po Fook Hill Ancestral Hall in Hong Kong. Cardboard replicas of luxury products, made to be burned in offerings to deceased relatives, have become increasingly elaborate.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: The luxury brand wants Hong Kong shops to stop selling cardboard replicas of its shoes, bags and other products to be burned as offerings to the dead.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: An Army Captain Takes Obama to Court Over ISIS Fight
item.media:description: Capt. Nathan Michael Smith
item.description: Capt. Nathan Michael Smith, an intelligence officer, voices strong support for fighting the Islamic State, but says Congress needs to approve it.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Defending Their Nation’s Honor on Social Media: #PanamaIsMoreThanPapers
item.media:description: Panama City in April. After the Panama Papers scandal, Panamanians took to social media with multilingual, pro-Panama hashtags, often accompanied by photos of beaches, sunsets, mountains and happy, carefree people.
item.description: Panamanians have erupted in patriotic fervor on Twitter in reaction to the negative attention that followed the release of the Panama Papers.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: In China, an iPhone May Not Necessarily Be a Phone
item.media:description: Xintong Tiandi’s iPhone leather goods. The Chinese manufacturer’s legal victory is just one of a spate of high-profile trademark and piracy cases in China.
item.description: A Chinese leather goods maker has won the right to sell its wares under the iPhone name, in the latest twist in the country for popular international brands.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: European Court of Justice Upholds Strict Rules on Tobacco
item.media:description: A customer sampled flavors for electronic cigarettes at the “Vapexpo” fair in Bordeaux, France, in 2014.
item.description: The body rejected industry challenges to uphold curbs that ban menthol, require new health warnings and set limits on e-cigarettes.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY

item.title: What in the World: A Nickname for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi? There’s No Short Answer
item.media:credit: Cari Vander Yacht and Erik Blad
item.description: Western notions of first and last names don’t really apply in Myanmar, presenting a quandary for people who speak or write about its leading political figure.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: What in the World: What’s That You’re Wearing? A Guide to Muslim Veils
item.description: Veils for Muslim women come in all sizes, shapes and colors — and with terminology that can mean different things in different places.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: What in the World: India’s Answer to Global Warming: Cows That Belch Less
item.media:credit: Illustration by Antonio de Luca; Photo by Subhash Sharma/ZUMA Press, Corbis
item.description: Cows, goats and other ruminant animals in India release 13 tons of methane every year. Scientists are studying breeds and food, hoping to reduce their output.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: What in the World: Brazil Ponders an Erotic Theme Park, With No Sex Allowed
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photo by druvo/istock
item.description: ErotikaLand will promote a healthy approach to sex, its investors say, though anyone hoping to test what they learn will be sent to a nearby motel.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: European Union Proposes Visa-Free Travel for Turks
item.media:description: Migrants and refugees in a camp near the Greek port of Chios Island as they wait to learn their fate.
item.description: The plan is a significant step for the bloc as it struggles to come to terms with the migrant crisis and hew to its humanitarian values.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sinosphere: China May Release Last Known Tiananmen Prisoner in October
item.media:description: Tiananmen Square on June 2, 1989. More than 1,500 people were sentenced to prison after the crackdown that began a day later.
item.description: The man, Miao Deshun, was convicted of arson for throwing a basket onto a burning tank and received a reduction in his sentence in March.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Only Way to Solve Iraq’s Political Crisis
item.description: After years of corruption and sectarianism, the country’s political class desperately needs new blood.
item.dc:creator: ZAID al-ALI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Make Britain Great Again
item.media:description: Boris Johnson in Manchester, England, last month.
item.description: Some call Boris Johnson Britain's Donald Trump. But I do not think Mr. Trump speaks Latin.
item.dc:creator: TANYA GOLD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why We Need a Foreign Policy Elite
item.media:description: Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger at the White House in 1972.
item.description: Donald Trump is wrong: America’s global security relies on its diplomatic and policy establishment.
item.dc:creator: EVAN THOMAS

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
